text.17_Daf, 23_Line: What constitutes the beginning of haircutting?
text.17_Daf, 20_Line: nor sit down to eat, not even a small meal.
text.17_Daf, 37_Line: One speaks of his [the Babylonians' practice] and the other of his [the Palestinians' practice].
text.17_Daf, 21_Line: Why not in the first place? Because one may prolong the meal.
text.17_Daf, 28_Line: When one takes off his coat.
text.17_Daf, 2_Line: One interrupts for the reading of the Shema', but not for the prayer (the 'Amida.
text.17_Daf, 29_Line: And what is the beginning of tanning?
text.17_Daf, 16_Line: After all we speak here of the usual haircut. Why may not one sit down at the beginning? Because the shears may be broken.
text.17_Daf, 18_Line: Nor a tannery if only to inspect it.
text.17_Daf, 26_Line: What constitutes the beginning of a bath?
text.17_Daf, 19_Line: Why not at the outset? Because one may notice that his goods are being spoiled, and that will worry him;
text.17_Daf, 17_Line: Thus one may not enter the bathhouse if only for sweating. Why not at the outset? Because one may faint.
text.17_Daf, 30_Line: When one tied his apron round his shoulders.
text.17_Daf, 22_Line: Nor to a law suit, even if at the end of it. Why not in the first place? Because he may find a new plea for changing the decision
text.17_Daf, 0_Line: MISHNAH: One does not sit down before the barber, close to the time of the afternoon prayer, unless he has already said his prayer. Neither shall he enter the bath house or a tannery, or sit down to eat or begin a law suit;
text.17_Daf, 1_Line: but if they have begun it, they need not interrupt it. ...
text.17_Daf, 25_Line: When the sheet is spread on one's knee.
